audio_caption: The audio opens with a male speaker teasingly setting up a story about a "real famous rapper" and a "real famous R&B chick," emphasizing that a "pimp had a naked recording of them" and that "he could have made millions of dollars". He suggests that it would "blow Kim Kardashian shit out the water", hyping up the magnitude of the pairing. He implies that the two people in the story "weren't supposed to be together". The speaker then asks "Are they still together now?" in a playfully surprised tone. A brief "Wow!" exclamation is heard. The audio transitions into trap music with a heavy bass and is abruptly cut off. A male voice says "Yeah, we on Boss Talk one-on-one".
The clip begins with a male speaker stating he has a story. He adds that he is going to ask if the listener knows about it. He suspects the listener is familiar with the story.

The audio clip starts with a male speaker reminiscing about a guest on his radio show. He recalls the guest's return months later, visibly upset. He then quotes the guest expressing distress over a woman stealing money and attempting to pay for a "choosing fee." Another male speaker then interjects, acknowledging the story and linking it to a song. The initial speaker confirms the connection and then a third speaker begins to share his perspective.

The clip starts with one male speaker discussing how a lot of women "wanted to choose up on" someone named Pimp because they resonate with his music, noting Pimp wanted to be in the game but was also a family man. He emphasizes Pimp loved his wife and kids, and that his wife was always supportive, even while he was in jail. The speaker mentions visiting Pimp in jail and writing letters, indicating Pimp had bitterness towards some people. Overall, the speaker uses a casual and storytelling tone.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker recounting a story about someone who had "$250,000 worth of features" upon returning home and entering the studio. He speaks in an informal, conversational tone, suggesting familiarity with the topic and a desire to share inside information. He references "Bum B" agreeing with "Free Pimp C" and acknowledges another side to the story, but refrains from elaborating further. The speaker mentions knowledge of the situation, stating, "I know about everything". The clip concludes with him speaking on Pimp C.

The clip begins with a male speaker discussing a person's name and family, noting their feelings that "whoever was using his name should have been Chun K's momma," suggesting concern for the mother's well-being. Another male voice interjects with questions about the mother's care, expressing skepticism and confusion. The first speaker responds with more detail, clarifying that he does not know the specifics. A third male voice offers a personal story. The first speaker then explains that they do not "give a fuck what motherfuckers do" as long as they take care of their family. He states that Pimp would always say that to him. He concludes with a mention of “intails.”

The audio clip begins with two male speakers, one recounting a story in a conversational and intrigued tone, sharing information about a famous rapper and R&B singer captured on tape. He claims that the tape could have been worth millions of dollars and might still exist. The second male speaker then expresses shock and curiosity, with laughter and interjections. The first speaker confirms having tried to get the tape. The second speaker questions him, then the first reiterates the significance of the involved figures in the music industry.

The audio features a conversation with a casual and somewhat slangy tone, where one speaker discusses a person who was "really getting it at one time." He elaborates on how this person was involved in "a lot of shit" and how people often do "dumb shit" before they become famous. He mentions that there are female artists who do "dumb shit" to "get up". The speaker then notes that this is human and then the sound switches. Another speaker mentions they are going to switch gears on the conversation. The sound then transitions to a statement about people being mad because they want to hear stories from the speakers. The speaker indicates that what they were discussing was good stuff.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker inquiring about a past collaboration with 50 Cent, specifically, if it occurred before meeting Pimp C. He speaks in a casual and conversational tone. The speaker confirms he knew Pimp C at the time. Then, another male speaker, possibly the same one, remembers previous events, placing the collaboration before Pimp C's jail time. Further clarifying, the speaker notes he was advocating for Pimp C, even while working with other artists like Little John and 2 Short. Pimp C acknowledged him and they began collaborating on music videos, about six or seven, and around six albums. The speaker clarifies that he still attended Player Anthem's video with all casts. The first male speaker asks him to explain that. After, the second speaker mentions Pimp C called him to request pimps to be in the video.

The audio begins with two male speakers discussing pimps seen in a video, with one mentioning names like "Valentino." He emphasizes that he's not a hater and welcomed everyone, expressing indifference to being in a video and selling DVDs in malls. In the background, a light and consistent scratching sound can be heard. A brief musical interlude follows, featuring an electronic instrumental beat, upbeat and modern in style. Another male voice speaks over the beat, stating "Yeah, we on boss talk 101."
